Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk file
exit 0

if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi

isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk file-debuginfo
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: file bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description:
An update for file is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7. The file command is used to identify a particular file according to the type of data the file contains. It can identify many different file types, including Executable and Linkable Format (ELF) binary files, system libraries, RPM packages, and different graphics formats.
For detailed information on changes in this release, see the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.3 Release Notes linked from the References section.
Users of file are advised to upgrade to these updated packages.
Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
